questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Accuracy
correct: Accuracy refers to how closely the measured value agrees with the 'true' value

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Precision
correct: Precision refers to how closely individual measurements agree with each other without reference to any 'true' value

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Systematic Error
correct: A systematic error is one that occurs according to some fixed rule or pattern such that they yield a consistent over-estimation or under-estimation of the true value of the measured quantity

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Random Error
correct: A random error is one that occurs without a fixed pattern such that a set of measurements done under the same conditions have an equally likely chance of being greater or less than the true value

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Scalar
correct: A scalar is a quantity which has magnitude only

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Vector
correct: A vector is a quantity which has both magnitude and direction

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Displacement
correct: Displacmement of an object is its distance from a fixed point in a specific direction

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Average speed
correct: Average speed of a body is defined as total distance travelled over total time taken

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Velocity
correct: The velocity of a body is defined as the rate of change of displacement

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Acceleration
correct: The acceleration of a body is defined as the rate of change of velocity

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Mass
correct: The mass of a body is a measure of its resistance to change in state of motion

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Momentum
correct: The momentum of a body is defined as the product of its mass and its velocity

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Force
correct: The force exerted by X on Y is defined as the rate of change in the momentum of Y produced by X

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Impulse
correct: The impulse of a force is defined as the product of the force and the time of impact of the force

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Newton's Second Law of Motion
correct: The rate of change in the momentum of a body is proportional to the resultant external force that acts on it, and the change in momentum is in the direction of the force

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Newton's Third Law of Motion
correct: When a body A exerts a force on body B, B exerts a reaction force on A that is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the action force

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Principle of Conservation of Linear Momentum
correct: In the absence of external forces, the total momentum of bodies in a system remains constant

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Collision
correct: An interaction between two or more bodies that is usually short in duration

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Elastic collision
correct: A collision in which the total kinectic energy after the collision is equal to that before the collision is called a (perfectly) elastic collision

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Inelastic collision
correct: A collision in which the total kinectic energy after the collision is less than that before the collision

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Perfectly/Completely inelastic collision
correct: A collision in which the loss in total kinectic energy is so great that the bodies do not seperate, but move together with a constant velocity

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Superelastic collision
correct: A collision in which the total kinectic energy after a collision is more than that before (like in an explosion)

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Hooke's Law
correct: Hooke's Law states that extension (or compression) in a material is directly proportional to the applied force, provided that the limit of proportionality is not exceeded

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Pressure
correct: Pressure is the normal force per unit area

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Upthrust (Archimedes Principle)
correct: Uptrust is the upward force exerted by a fluid on a submerged or floating object
It arises due to the difference in pressure between the upper and lower surfaces of the object
It is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the weight of the fluid displaced by a submerged or floating object

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Principle of Flotation
correct: Principle of Flotation states that when an object floats in equilibrium, uptrust is equal to the qweight of the object

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: the Moment of a Force
correct: The moment of a force about a pivot is the product of the force and the perpendicular distance from the pivot to the line of action of the force

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: a couple
correct: a pair of forces which are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction,
and whose lines of action do not coincide

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Torque
correct: The torque of a couple is the product of one of the forces and the perpendicular distance between the forces

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Principle of moments
correct: Principle of moments states that for a body in equilibrium, the sum of clockwise moments about any point is equal to the sum of anti-clockwise moments about the same point

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: What are the conditions for a body to be in equilibrium
correct: It is a body where the resultant force acting on the body is zero (in translational equilibrium)
and the resultant torque on the body is zero (in rotational equilibrium)

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Work Done
correct: Work done by a force on a body is the product of the force and the displacement in the direction of the force

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Principle of Conservation of Energy
correct: Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, but it can be transformed from one form to another

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Energy Efficiency
correct: The energy efficiency n of a device is the ratio of useful energy output to the energy input

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Power
correct: The rate at which work is done

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Angular Displacement
correct: The angle of rotation of a body about an axis in a specific direction from a reference point

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Angular velocity
correct: The rate of change of angular displacement of a body

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation and Gravitational Force
correct: Every particle of matter in the universe attracts every other particle with a gravitational force
that is directly proportional to the product of the massess of the particles
and inversely proportional to the square of distance between them

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Gravitational Field
correct: A region of space in which a mass experiences a force due to the presence of another mass

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Gravitational Field Strength
correct: The gravitational field strength at a point in a gravitational field is defined as the gravitational force per unit mass acting on a test mass placed at that point

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: What are the conditions needed for a planet to remain in Geostationary Orbit?
correct: The object must be directly above the Earth's Equator
Have an orbital period equal to the Earth's rotational period
Be orbiting from West to East

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Gravitational Potential Energy
correct: The gravitational potential energy of a mass at a point in a field is defined as the work done by an external agent in bringing that mass from infinity to that point
without any change in kinetic energyof the test mass

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Gravitational Potential
correct: The gravitational potential at a point in a field is defined as the work done per unit mass by an external agent in bringing a test mass from infinity to that point
without any change in kinetic energyof the test mass

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Simple Harmonic Motion
correct: For a particle performing simple harmonic motion, the acceleration is directly proportional to the displacement from the equilibrium position
The acceleration is always directed towards the equilibrium position OR the direction of acceleration is always opposite to the displacement

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Period
correct: Time taken for the particle to complete one oscillation

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Equilibrium Position
correct: Midpoint of oscillation. It is the position at which no net force acts on the particle

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Displacement
correct: Displacement of the particle at a particular instant is its distance from its equilibrium position O in a specific direction

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Amplitude
correct: The maximum displacement from its equilibrium position

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Frequency
correct: The number of oscillations performed per unit time

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Phase
correct: The stage of an oscillation the particle is in at a particulat instant

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Angular frequency
correct: Rate of change of phase of the particle

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Free Oscillation
correct: An oscillation where the object oscillated under a restoring force only, without any other external forces on it

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Damped Oscillation
correct: A damped oscillation is an oscillation that lose energy until it comes to a stop due to resistive forces

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Forced Oscillation
correct: When a driving force or driver is applied periodically (at regular time intervals) to an oscillating system, the system is made to oscillate at the frequency of the driver

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Resonance
correct: The phenomenon in which there is a maximum transfer of energy from the driver to the oscillating system in a forced oscillation.
It occurs when the driving frequency matches the natural frquency of the oscillating system
The oscillating system achieves maximum amplitude during resonance

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Thermal equilibrium
correct: A situation in which there is no net exchange of energy when two objects are placed in thermal contact

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Absolute scale of temperature
correct: The temperature is a theoretical scale and is independent of the property of any particular substance
This temperature has a natural minimum which is called "absolute zero". The substance with this temperature has the smallest possible internal energy

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: State what you understand by the internal energyof a system.Explain with reference to the energies of the molecules of the system
correct: The internal energy of a system is the sum of the microscopic kinetic energy and microscopic potential energy of all the atoms / molecules in the system.
The microscopic kinetic energy and microscopic potential energy are randomly distributed among the particles.

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Specific Heat Capacity
correct: The specific heat capacity of a substance is the quantity of heat required to produce a unit change in temperature per unit mass of that substance

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Specific Latent Heat of Fusion
correct: The amount of heat required per unit mass to change a substance from solid state to liquid state without any change in temperature

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Specific Latent Heat of Vaporization
correct: The amount of heat required per unit mass to change a substance from liquid state to gas state without any change in temperature

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: First Law of Thermodynamics
correct: In a closed system, the increase (cannot be change) in internal energy is equal to the sum of heat supplied to the system and the work done on the system

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Transverse Wave
correct: A wave in which the oscillations of the particles are perpendicular to the direction of propagation of the waves themselves

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Longitudinal Waves
correct: A wave in which the oscillations of the particles are parallel to the direction of propagation of the wave.

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Wave Speed
correct: The distance travelled by the wave per unit time

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Wavefront
correct: An Imaginary line joining all the points of the wave that have the same phase

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Ray
correct: The line drawn in the direction of the wave motion which is used to indicate the path taken by the wave.
Rays are always perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Phase Difference
correct: The measure of how much one particle is out of step with one other particle of the same/ another wave

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Intensity
correct: The intensity of a wave is the rate of flow of energy per unit area perpendicular to the direction of the wave

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Polarisation
correct: A process by which a wave's oscillations are made to occur in a single plane only

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: When two waves meet, the resultant displacement is the vector sum of the displacements due to each individual wave

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Coherence
correct: Sources are said to be coherent if they have constant phase difference

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Formation of Stationary Waves
correct: Stationary waves result from the superposition of two waves of equal amplitude and frequency travelling with the same speed but in opposite directions

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Explain why the satellite is able to orbit the Earth at constant speed
correct: The direction of velocity of the satellite is perpendicular to the gravitational forceexerted by Earth on it. [1]

The magnitude of the gravitational force exerted by Earth on the satellite is just sufficient to provide the required centripetal force for the satellite to orbit about the Earth. Hence this force will only change the direction of velocity of the satellite so that it orbits about Earth, but does not cause the speed of the satellite to change. [1]

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: A journalist reported that “the astronauts in the space station are able to conduct experiments in zero-gravity.” Comment on the validity of the statement.
correct: While the astronauts may experience apparent weightlessness (as normal contact force is zero), the gravitational field strength is not zero

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Explain why the amplitude of vibration of the car becomes much larger at a particular speed when the car is driven over a series of equally spaced bumps.
correct: The bumps exert a periodic driving force on the car [1],
which has a frequency that changes with the speed of the car as it moves over the bumps. [1]
When the driving (bumping) frequency is equal to the car’s natural frequency, resonance occurs and the amplitude of vibration becomes a maximum. [1]

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Explained what is meant by Geostationary Orbit.
correct: A geostationary orbit is one in which a satellite is observed to be staying over the same place on the earth as the earth rotates. [1]

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Explain what is meant by the internal energy of a system.
correct: The sum of a random distribution of the kinetic and potential energies associated withthe molecules of the system

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Explain how an a-x graph would show that the ball exhibits simple harmonic motion.
correct: The shape is the same: acceleration always proportional to displacement [1]
Shape is flipped: acceleration and displacement always opposite direction [1]

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: A rise in temperature of a body is always associated with an increase in its internal energy, but an increase in a body’s internal energy is not always associated with a rise in its temperature. Explain.
correct: Temperature is a measure of the body’s average internal kinetic energy. A rise in its temperature is the result of an increase in its internal kinetic energy (and total internal energy).An increase in total internal energy could be due to the increase in internal potential energy i.e. that in melting and boiling which occurs at a fixed temperature.

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: One condition for a satellite to be in geostationary orbit of a celestial body is that the orbit of the satellite must lie in the plane containing theequator. Explain why this is necessary
correct: As the direction of the gravitational force is directed towards the center of the celestial body, the centre of the celestial bodyis also the center of the circular motion of the satellite.

Hence if it is not over the equator, the circular motion of the satellite would have varying latitude(i.e. it would be in a circular motion which would take it from the northern hemisphere to the southern hemisphere).

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: When a cup of tea is stirred with a teaspoon in a horizontal circle, the tea level is observed to change from a horizontal line to a curved line, as shown in Fig.5.2 Explain why the tea level does not remain horizontal during the stirring
correct: During stirring, the tea particles are moving in a horizontal circle.
The tea particles nearer the wall of the cup move in a circle of larger radius. Therefore they require a larger centripetal force, given that their angular velocities are the same.
Hence the fluid pressure nearer the wall of the cup has to be larger. That is why the depth of the tea from its surface is greater nearer the wall of the cup than in the middle of the cup.

questions.question: Explain why the principle of conservation of momentum is not observed between _
correct: The system is not an isolated system/experiences an external force due to _. This violates the principle of conservation of momentum.

questions.subject: H2 Physics
questions.question: Saturn has rings of rock andice in steady orbit about its equatorial plane, as shown in Fig. 4.2. Explain why, for steady orbit,the rings must be in a plane that includes the centre of Saturn. Fig. 4.2
correct: At the equatorial plane, the rock & ice experience gravitational force which is directed towards the centre of Saturn.

This gravitational force which provides the centripetal force allows the rock & ice to remain in steady orbit about the equator (which includes the centre of Saturn). OR At any plane which does not include the centre of Saturn, the rock & ice experience gravitational force which is directed towards the centre of Saturn. A component of the gravitational force provides the centripetalforce for circular orbit about the plane and the other component of the gravitational force (perpendicular to the plane) cause the rock & ice to move towards the equator; hence a non-steady orbit (which does not include the centre of Saturn).
